Ovarian cancer is also potentially hereditary, with an increased frequency of cases seen in women with mutations in BRCA 1/2 and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer. Treatment includes surgical resection and debulking plus chemotherapy. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to maximize survival. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, and G. Colon cancer (Choice A) may present with symptoms of a bowel obstruction, especially if left-sided (descending colon). Classic symptoms of left-sided colon cancer include weight loss, tenesmus, constipation, narrow stools, and large bowel obstruction. Right-sided (ascending colon) lesions classically present with occult bleeding and iron deficiency anemia. Endometrial cancer (Choice B) classically arises in older women who have been chronically exposed to uninterrupted estrogen stimulation (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, using tamoxifen, using exogenous hormones). Any unexplained vaginal bleeding in a postmenopausal woman should be investigated, as endometrial carcinoma may be present. Gastric cancer (Choice C) classically presents with weight loss, early satiety, and melena in a patient with a history of smoking, peptic ulcer disease, chronic gastritis, or frequent consumption of nitrate-containing foods. Gastric outlet obstruction is a potential complication, which presents as nausea, left upper quadrant and epigastric discomfort, and nonbilious emesis containing partially digested food. Metastatic breast cancer (Choice D) most commonly spreads to the bone, lung, and brain, and would be less likely to present with omental and peritoneal metastases. Metastatic cervical cancer (Choice E) often invades locally into the bladder or rectum and does not classically present with omental or peritoneal metastasis. When distant spread occurs, the lung is a common site of metastatic disease. Pancreatic cancer (Choice G) classically presents with painless jaundice, because of obstruction of the distal common bile duct. When symptomatic, patients may experience abdominal pain, weight loss, dark urine, pale stools, and symptoms of malabsorption such as vitamin deficiencies and steatorrhea. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 22 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
22. An 8-year-old girl has had migrating polyarthralgia and fever for 4 days . She appears ill. Examination shows an evanescent rash . Her left knee is red, swollen , and tender . The chest is clear to auscultation . A grade 4/6 ,
holosystolic apical murmur is heard with radiation to the axilla . There is no organomegaly . Which of the following is the most likely cardiac abnormality?

question_stem: the most likely cardiac abnormality?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) may present with migratory polyarthralgia, pancarditis (pericarditis, myocarditis, or endocarditis), subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea, fever, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and short PR interval following an infection from group A streptococci, most often pharyngitis. The mitral valve is the most commonly affected. Antibodies to M protein enhance host defenses against group A streptococci but can result in an autoimmune attack against self-antigens through molecular mimicry. This can result in valve inflammation and acute regurgitation. Chronic mitral regurgitation, prolapse, or stenosis can result as potential long-term sequelae.

distractor_explanations.A: Aortic stenosis presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is heard best at the upper right sternal border and radiates to the carotid arteries. It classically occurs secondary to age-related fibrotic and calcific changes of the valve but can occur earlier in life in cases of bicuspid aortic valve or chronic rheumatic disease. Tetralogy of Fallo! (Choice C) consists of pulmonary infundibular stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy, resulting in a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis first noted in infancy. The murmur heard with Tetralogy of Fallo! relates to the underlying ventricular septal defect, characterized by a holosystolic murmur heard best in the lower left sternal border, and to the pulmonic stenosis, characterized by a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in the pulmonic listening area. Tricuspid regurgitation (Choice D) demonstrates a holosystolic murmur heard best in the lower left sternal border. The tricuspid valve is less commonly affected than the mitral or aortic valves in ARF. Ventricular septal defect (VSD) (Choice E) is characterized by a holosystolic murmur heard best in the lower left sternal border. VSD generally presents at birth and is not associated with ARF. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 23 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
23. A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department 60 minutes after the sudden onset of tearing chest pain radiating to his back. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications . He does not smoke . He is
190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m 2 His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg in his right arm and 70/40 mm Hg in his left arm.
•
Pulse oximetry on 2 L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 100%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . The lungs are clear to auscultation . Heart sounds are normal. Pulses are
difficult to palpate in the left upper extremity. Peripheral pulses are otherwise normal. A chest x-ray shows a widened upper mediastinum . An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no acute changes . Which of the following is the
most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Labetalol is a first-line antihypertensive medication used to decrease blood pressure in the setting of presumed aortic dissection, which classically presents with severe, acute, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, differential blood pressures between extremities, and a widened mediastinum on a chest x-ray. To prevent further progression of the dissection flap, controlling the patient's heart rate and blood pressure is the first priority. An intravenous ~-adrenergic blocking agent should be used with a goal of decreasing the heart rate to approximately 60/min and the blood pressure to less than 100 to 120 mm Hg systolic and 60 to 80 mm Hg diastolic. Decreasing the heart rate helps prevent the advancement of the dissection flap and resultant occlusion of branch vessels by limiting the pulse pressure differential. Labetalol is a nonspecific adrenoreceptor blocker that targets both ar and ~radrenoreceptors, making it an ideal choice for the management of the patient's heart rate, cardiac contractility, and vascular resistance.

distractor_explanations.A: Administration of heparin would be appropriate in the management of an acute coronary syndrome. Administering therapeutic anticoagulation in the setting of an aortic dissection increases the risk for severe thoracic hemorrhage and exsanguination if there is an associated aneurysm and/or damage to the tunica adventitia. Administration of nitroglycerin (Choice C) may be appropriate in cases of aortic dissection for blood pressure control if the goal is not met with adrenoreceptor blockade; however, it would follow administration of a ~ adrenergic blocking agent to prevent reflex tachycardia and widening of pulse pressure. Fiberoptic intubation (Choice D) may be appropriate for a patient with a compromised airway, but in cases without an impending threat to the airway would be superseded by management of the immediate life threatening condition, the patient's aortic dissection.
distractor_explanations.E: Pericardiocentesis is appropriate in cases of pericardia! effusion and/or tamponade, which would present following symptoms of pericarditis, or with muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and hypotension iftamponade from any cause is present. Pulsus paradoxus may be seen on examination. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 24 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
24. A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of ulcers on her right ankle for 6 months . There is no history of recent trauma . She has a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with insulin for the past 4 years
and a 2-year history of chronic bilateral ankle swelling . Her temperature is 37.?°C (99.9°F) , pulse is 82/min , and blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg. Examination shows ulceration of the medial aspect of the right ankle . There is
bilateral lower leg and pedal edema with patches of brown pigmentation . Peripheral pulses are present and normal. Which of the following is the most likely pathogenesis of this condition?

question_stem: the most likely pathogenesis of this condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Venous insufficiency presents with dependent, pitting edema that improves with compression and elevation, along with paresthesia and hyperpigmentation of the skin (e.g., stasis dermatitis). In severe cases, chronic circulatory insufficiency can result in skin breakdown, leading to the development of open ulcers, classically along the medial aspect of the ankle. Venous insufficiency often results from deep venous thrombosis with resultant damage to the valves. When the thrombus resolves, the residual vessel may be dysfunctional from damage to the valve leaflets, valve annulus, or increased diameter of the native vessel. This prevents the vessel from functioning effectively and results in stagnant or retrograde venous flow secondary to gravity. Treatment includes wound care for the ulcer and measures to reverse the venous insufficiency such as optimizing venous return, diuresis, and improving circulatory function by optimizing cardiac, vascular, and kidney function.

vignette.presentation:
25. A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of generalized itching and fatigue . He has chronic renal failure secondary to glomerulonephritis and receives hemodialysis three times weekly.
Examination shows no abnormalities except for a patent arteriovenous fistula in the left forearm . His serum calcium concentration is 8.3 mg/dl , serum phosphorus concentration is 4.1 mg/dl , and serum intact parathyroid
hormone concentration is 485 pg/ml (N=10-65) . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

It is useful in cases of suspected acute cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, or biliary obstruction with indeterminate ultrasonography findings. It does not permit tissue sampling such as biopsy or therapeutic interventions such as stenting. These features may result in false negative liver biopsy results and should prompt targeted sampling via ERCP. Exploratory laparotomy (Choice E) involves the surgical evaluation of the peritoneal cavity and is commonly employed in the diagnosis and management of abdominal trauma, bowel obstruction, peritonitis, and undifferentiated cases of an acute abdomen. It does not have an immediate role in the diagnosis or management of cholangiocarcinoma. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
26. A previously healthy 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of mild hearing loss and ringing in her right ear and a decreased sense of taste on the right. She also has had episodes of
unsteadiness during this period and has had trouble understanding speech . She has not had nausea , vomiting , or vertigo . Examination shows no abnormalities . Audiometry shows predominantly high-frequency neural hearing
loss on the right. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) commonly presents with symptoms of hearing loss, vertigo, and ataxia, often slow in onset and progressive over a subacute to chronic period. Classically, these tumors occur at the cerebellopontine angle of the brain stem and are associated with neurofibromatosis. They may exert mass effect on cranial nerves within their proximity or invade the nerves from which they arise, often the facial nerve, vestibulocochlear nerve, or adjacent nerves. Facial nerve involvement manifests as facial asymmetry because of loss of skeletal muscle innervation and occasionally presents with diminished taste perception involving the ipsilateral anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Vestibulocochlear nerve palsy can present with diminished hearing or tinnitus (cochlear branch) on the ipsilateral side, and vertigo or ataxia may occur (vestibular branch) because of impaired proprioception from loss of input from the ipsilateral vestibule. In cases of larger masses, disruption of brain stem tracts and increased intracranial pressure can result.

distractor_explanations.B: presents with a classic triad of hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo, and is caused by fluid overload within the vestibulocochlear apparatus. It would not cause a decreased sense of taste.
distractor_explanations.C: Meningitis typically presents with headache, fever, photophobia, phonophobia, and neck stiffness, as well as possible Kernig or Brudzinski signs noted on examination. It may be caused by bacterial, viral, fungal, or parasitic infections. Cranial nerve deficits may result, but a chronic presentation involving cranial nerves only would be rare.
distractor_explanations.D: Otosclerosis results in dysfunction of the ossicles and causes conductive hearing loss; neurologic symptoms of ataxia would be unlikely. Pituitary adenoma (Choice E) can present with mass-like symptoms such as a headache or bitemporal hemianopsia, or with symptoms caused by the functional production of a hormone from the tumor (e.g., galactorrhea secondary to a prolactinoma). Because of the position of the pituitary gland within the sella turcica, symptoms involving the facial nerve or vestibulocochlear nerve would be unlikely. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 27 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
27. A previously healthy 15-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of difficulty breathing and sharp chest pain that began during track practice . She is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs
55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 16 kg/m 2 On arrival , her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 70/min , and respirations are 28/min . Breath sounds are decreased over the lateral chest on the right ; there is hyperresonance to percussion .
Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of these findings?

choices.text: Air collection in the pleural space

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pneumothorax results from air entering the intrapleural space from either an external (e.g., stab wound) or internal (e.g., ruptured bleb or bronchus, bronchopleural fistula) source. As the air accumulates within the space, the lung parenchyma becomes compressed, resulting in respiratory distress, reduced breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and in severe cases, tension on the mediastinal structures impeding venous return resulting in hypotension. A spontaneous primary pneumothorax can occur in a tall, thin, young person because of the rupture of a pulmonary bleb, classically in a young athlete and often during physical exertion. Small pneumothoraces can be managed with serial examinations and repeat chest x-rays to confirm resolution. When the lesion is larger than 20 to 30% of the hemithoracic volume, a chest tube should be placed to evacuate the pneumothorax and reinflate the lung to prevent the development of a persistent or permanent pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax should be immediately decompressed with emergent needle thoracostomy to prevent hemodynamic collapse.

distractor_explanations.B: Alveolar atelectasis may present with shortness of breath or be asymptomatic depending on the size and extent. A small, subsegmental atelectatic region may be completely asymptomatic, whereas if an entire lung is involved, the patient may present with shortness of breath, severe hypoxia, diminished ipsilateral breath sounds, and dullness to percussion. Narrowing of moderate-sized airways (Choice C) presents with poor air movement, wheezing or rhonchi, and cough, and describes the pathophysiology of bronchitis. Asthma classically results in narrowing of the small airways. Pleural inflammation (Choice D) presents with pleuritic chest pain, often following a viral respiratory infection. Occasionally, a friction rub may be heard on auscultation, but often the examination and vital signs are unremarkable. Pulmonary parenchymal inflammation (Choice E) describes pneumonitis or pneumonia, which typically presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough; hyperresonance to percussion would not be expected. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 28 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
28. A previously healthy 42-year-old woman , gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of discharge from the left nipple . She is sexually active and uses an oral contraceptive . Her temperature is 37°C
(98.6°F) , pulse is 90/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Examination shows no breast masses . A serosanguineous discharge is easily expressed from the left nipple . Mammography shows no
areas of microcalcification . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of the bile ducts, characteristically presents late in its course with signs of biliary tree obstruction, including abdominal discomfort, weight loss, nausea, jaundice, and pruritus. Patients may report dark urine or light, pale stools. Many persons have no risk factors; however, those with a history of cirrhosis, sclerosing cholangitis, hepatitis B or C, liver fluke infection, and ulcerative colitis may be at increased risk. Diagnosis occurs through imaging of the abdomen with CT scan or MRI, which may disclose a variety of findings from bile duct wall thickening, a focal mass, or only dilation of bile ducts proximal to the presumed lesion location. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) allows for the potential direct visualization of the lesion location, bile duct scrapings or biopsy for definitive diagnosis, and stenting of any associated occlusion. Laboratory analysis typically discloses obstructive (direct) hyperbilirubinemia and increased alkaline phosphatase activity. Treatment includes surgical resection and chemotherapy; however, the condition is often late-stage or terminal at the time of diagnosis. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Measurement of serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) concentration (Choice A) is sometimes increased in cholangiocarcinoma; however, it is nonspecific and is also increased in colorectal carcinoma along with other various malignancies. It may be followed during treatment to assess treatment response but does not have a specific role in diagnosis. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy (HIDA scan) (Choice C) evaluates the patency of the hepatobiliary tree and gallbladder. It is useful in cases of suspected acute cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, or biliary obstruction with indeterminate ultrasonography findings. It does not permit tissue sampling such as biopsy or therapeutic interventions such as stenting. Liver biopsy (Choice D) is useful in the diagnosis of conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma, though cholangiocarcinoma is generally small and confined to the biliary tree. These features may result in false negative liver biopsy results and should prompt targeted sampling via ERCP. Exploratory laparotomy (Choice E) involves the surgical evaluation of the peritoneal cavity and is commonly employed in the diagnosis and management of abdominal trauma, bowel obstruction, peritonitis, and undifferentiated cases of an acute abdomen. It does not have an immediate role in the diagnosis or management of cholangiocarcinoma. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
29. A 77-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of severe cramping pain in the lower abdomen . The pain has been constant for the past 16 hours. The abdomen is
markedly distended . A McBurney incisional scar is noted in the right lower quadrant. The x-ray shown was taken shortly after admission . Which of the following is the most
likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Mechanical obstruction of the small intestine

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A sigmoid volvulus results from twisting of the sigmoid mesentery, which can lead to large bowel obstruction and perforation or intestinal necrosis if not treated. Patients commonly present with symptoms secondary to a large bowel obstruction such as constipation, abdominal bloating, distention, nausea, and vomiting. Sigmoid volvulus typically demonstrates a coffee-bean appearance on abdominal x-rays with severe distention of the sigmoid colon. In patients without complications such as bowel ischemia or perforation, treatment requires detorsion of the sigmoid colon and mesentery through sigmoidoscopy with placement of a rectal tube to facilitate stool passage and maintain decompression. Recurrent sigmoid volvulus may require surgical colopexy or sigmoid colectomy.

distractor_explanations.A: Cecal cancer is often asymptomatic until late in the course. It is classically associated with occult gastrointestinal bleeding and iron deficiency anemia. lleoileal intussusception (Choice B) describes telescoping of one segment of ileum into an adjacent segment, which can cause intestinal ischemia or obstruction. It typically occurs because of a pathologic lead point (e.g., malignancy, stricture, lymphadenopathy), and presents with colicky pain and bloating. Abdominal x-rays are often nondiagnostic for the condition, which is better detailed on ultrasonography (children) or CT scan (adults), which will disclose the intussusceptum. Mechanical obstruction of the small intestine (Choice C) is typically acute, occurring because of adhesions, inflammatory bowel disease, strictures, malignancies, or hernias. It typically presents with abdominal pain, nausea, nonbloody and sometimes bilious emesis, hyperactive and high-pitched bowel sounds, and abdominal distention. X-rays may show dilated loops of small bowel with air-fluid levels. Paralytic ileus (Choice D) refers to intestinal hypomotility without a mechanical obstruction, most commonly occurring following surgery or in the setting of electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., end-stage kidney disease resulting in hyperkalemia). It typically presents with diffuse small and large bowel dilatation. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 30 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
30. A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 24 hours after the onset of severe abdominal cramps and nausea . During this period , she has vomited yellow-green material once and has had only two bowel
movements , which were small and liquid . During the past 6 months , she has had less severe abdominal cramps associated with diarrhea and a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss . She says the cramps have become more severe during
the past month . She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications . On arrival , she is in moderate distress . She appears pale. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (114 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m 2 Her temperature
is 37 .2°C (99°F) , pulse is 90/min , and blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows moderate distention with mild right lower quadrant tenderness . Her leukocyte count is 14,000/mm 3 A CT scan of the
•
abdomen shows thickening of the terminal ileum and air in the rectum . The colon is not dilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Upper gastrointestinal series with a water-soluble contrast and small bowel follow-through

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, most frequently involving the terminal ileum. It can arise anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract and is a subclass of inflammatory bowel disease. Most patients experience chronic abdominal cramping, bloody diarrhea, anemia, and weight loss. Examination often demonstrates generalized abdominal tenderness, sometimes worse in the right lower quadrant, and, depending on the severity and extent, may disclose complications such as enterocutaneous fistulas and extraintestinal manifestations such as uveitis. Severe Crohn disease can result in intestinal obstruction from stricture or inflammation, bowel perforation, intra-abdominal abscess, and the formation of additional fistulas. Diagnosis occurs through colonoscopy with biopsy, which is the best next step in the diagnosis of this patient. Laboratory analyses often disclose increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein concentration. Treatment is through anti-inflammatory medications, immunomodulators, and glucocorticoids, with complicated, severe cases sometimes requiring surgery including small bowel resection or colectomy.

distractor_explanations.A: Barium enema is used to evaluate the lumen of the large bowel to assist in the diagnosis of colonic neoplasms, strictures, fistulas, or postsurgical complications. It does not reliably image the distal small bowel and does not permit sampling of tissue for biopsy. Upper gastrointestinal series with a water-soluble contrast and small bowel follow-through (Choice B) studies are indicated when structural lesions involving the stomach or small bowel are suspected. This is most commonly indicated for the evaluation of small bowel pathology, such as duodenal atresia, malrotation with volvulus, and Crohn disease; however, it would not offer the opportunity to sample tissue through biopsy. MRI of the abdomen (Choice C) offers high-contrast resolution detail of soft-tissue structures within the abdomen. It can be used for the evaluation of a variety of intra-abdominal pathologies. MRI enterography techniques can be utilized to investigate sites of active or chronic bowel inflammation, although this would not permit tissue sampling. Capsule endoscopy (Choice D) is used in the diagnosis of jejunal and proximal ileal pathology located outside of the reachable field of view of upper endoscopy or colonoscopy. It is most commonly used in the workup of small bowel sources of gastrointestinal bleeding or neoplasia. It offers images only and cannot be used for tissue sampling. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 'I 31 . A 66-year-old man with unresectable squamous cell lung cancer has the acute onset of severe shortness of breath. An x-ray of the chest shows a unilateral pleural effusion . The patient has been receiving hospice care at home. Which of the following management strategies is most consistent with the patient's preference for hospice care? A) Initiation of systemic chemotherapy B) Radiation therapy C) Open pleurodesis D) Thoracentesis E) Tracheostomy CorrectAnswer: D. Hospice care generally carries the goal of providing an improved quality of life for a patient when a terminal condition is present. While the criteria for hospice eligibility vary by state and sometimes by individual hospice organization, there are general universally agreed-upon conditions for eligibility such that a life-limiting condition must be present, often with a prognosis of 6 months or less to live. Additionally, frequent hospitalizations; progressive weight loss or failure to thrive; terminal malignancy; advanced dementia, Alzheimer type; end-stage kidney disease without dialysis or transplant; and end-stage heart, lung, or liver failure are often conditions for which hospice eligibility exists. In such cases, a focus is placed on the patient's goals of care related to quality of life, and procedures or medical treatments that would improve such quality are undertaken in lieu of those that would limit the quality of life or cause undue distress without changing prognosis. Thoracentesis in the setting of terminal lung cancer would improve the patient's respiratory status and comfort without adding undue risk for pain. This is an appropriate intervention for a patient with terminal lung cancer and a large, compromising pleural effusion. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Initiation of systemic chemotherapy (Choice A), radiation therapy (Choice B), open pleurodesis (Choice C), and tracheostomy (Choice E) would all add undue discomfort and suffering without altering the patient's prognosis. These are contraindicated in a hospice patient with a terminal malignancy. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 32 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
32. A previously healthy 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a motor vehicle collision . She was an unrestrained front seat passenger . On arrival , she has pain and tingling in her right leg and
is unable to move it. Her pulse is 105/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. The right lower extremity is pale . The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are absent on the right. There is a posterior
dislocation of the right knee . Motor and sensory function is absent below the right knee . Following reduction of the dislocation and splinting of the right lower extremity , the patient is able to move the leg. Which of the following is
the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Venous duplex ultrasonography of the right lower extremity
CT scan of the right lower extremity

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of the bile ducts, characteristically presents late in its course with signs of biliary tree obstruction, including abdominal discomfort, weight loss, nausea, jaundice, and pruritus. vignette.presentation:
33. A 70-year-old man has a 2-year history of progressive dysphagia and intermittent regurgitation of undigested food . A barium swallow is shown . Which of the following is the most
likely cause?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A pharyngoesophageal (Zenker) diverticulum occurs within the hypopharynx, just above or at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. The mechanism of formation includes an uncoordinated swallowing mechanism, which results in muscle spasms of the cricopharyngeus leading to pulsion diverticula as the wall of the hypopharynx and superior esophagus weakens. Symptoms include halitosis, regurgitation of undigested food, and dysphagia. Barium swallow discloses a posterior, midline outpouching above or at the level of the cricopharyngeus. Treatment includes surgical repair and resection (diverticulectomy), plus dietary modifications to include soft or liquid foods.

distractor_explanations.A: Absence of peristalsis after swallowing occurs in the setting of autonomic neuropathy, cerebrovascular accident, and achalasia. It generally results in the failure of a food bolus to transit through the hypopharynx and/or esophagus, not in the focal formation of a hypopharyngeal diverticulum. Diffuse esophageal spasm (Choice C) presents with severe dysphagia and chest pain, often acutely in the setting of swallowing. It may also occur in the absence of swallowing, such as in association with gastroesophageal reflux disease. Barium swallow would disclose a "corkscrew" esophagus, not a focal hypopharyngeal diverticulum. Severe gastroesophageal reflux (Choice D) presents with cough, sour or metallic taste, chest discomfort, and nausea. It is often worse when supine or following the ingestion of trigger foods. It would not be expected to cause a focal hypopharyngeal diverticulum. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 34 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
34. A 37-year-old woman is scheduled for operative treatment of an umbilical hernia with incarcerated omentum under general anesthesia . During the operation , a solid nodule is excised , and a frozen section shows metastatic
carcinoma consistent with primary ovarian cancer . Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

question_stem: the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Close the operative site and discuss further treatment with the patient when she awakens
Place a central venous catheter with a subcutaneous injection port for chemotherapy and discuss further treatment with the patient when she awakens
Place a peritoneal dialysis catheter through the operative site for future chemotherapy and discuss further treatment with the patient when she awakens
Obtain consent from the next of kin and place a central venous catheter with a subcutaneous injection port for chemotherapy
Obtain consent from the next of kin and proceed with laparotomy and tumor debulking

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Incidental discoveries during unrelated surgery, when not immediately life-threatening, are appropriately managed by closing the operative site and discussing the findings with the patient when they regain decision making capacity following anesthesia. While discovery of malignancy in a young woman may immediately prompt the thought that treatment would be desired, the decision to pursue intervention is ultimately the patient's choice, upholding the ethical principle of autonomy.

distractor_explanations.B: Placing a central venous catheter with a subcutaneous injection port for chemotherapy and discussing further treatment with the patient when she awakens and placing a peritoneal dialysis catheter through the operative site for future chemotherapy and discussing further treatment with the patient when she awakens (Choice C) do not respect the patient's autonomy and do not consider her preferences in treatment. Obtain consent from the next of kin and place a central venous catheter with a subcutaneous injection port for chemotherapy (Choice D) and obtaining consent from the next of kin and proceeding with laparotomy and tumor debulking (Choice E) are also incorrect. These choices violate the patient's autonomy, and there is no suspicion of a lack of decision-making capacity outside of the time the patient is under anesthesia. In cases where the patient would not be able to make a decision because of an absence of capacity, a surrogate decision maker can be used. However, unless a procedure is urgent or emergent, there is no immediate need to consult a surrogate. The patient can recover capacity from the anesthesia with a decision made after further discussions. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 35 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
35. An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 months after she sustained a right hip fracture when she fell in her kitchen . Two years ago , she sustained a Colles fracture in a fall. Examination
today shows a well-healed scar over the right hip. Range of motion of the hip joint is full. Her serum calcium concentration is within the reference ranges ; her serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration is decreased . A DEXA scan
shows osteoporosis . Which of the following is the most likely additional serum abnormality in this patient ?

question_stem: the most likely additional serum abnormality in this patient ?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Osteoporosis occurs because of the loss of bone mineral density. The condition results from the interplay of three possible mechanisms: failure to achieve peak bone density, increased bone resorption, and decreased new bone formation. The condition is often asymptomatic until a traumatic injury results in a fracture, most commonly involving the hip, distal radius, or vertebrae. Classically, serum calcium, vitamin D, and magnesium concentrations are within the reference ranges; however, calcium handling in the bloodstream is key in the pathogenesis of osteoporosis. Hypocalcemia and hypovitaminosis D both lead to increased concentrations of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which results in increased osteoclast activity and bone resorption. Low concentrations of vitamin D are also associated with increased concentrations of PTH even when serum calcium is within the reference range. The diagnosis of osteoporosis is made based on DEXA scan once the bone density falls below 2.5 standard deviations of the mean for a young adult. Treatment includes correcting any modifiable risk factors, supplementing calcium and vitamin D, weight-bearing exercise therapy, and the use of osteoclast inhibitors (e.g., bisphosphonates).

distractor_explanations.A: hydroxylase activity results in a low active vitamin D concentration in the setting of end-stage kidney disease because of loss of parenchymal cells that synthesize the enzyme and the resultant inability to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, the active form. A deficiency of this enzyme would be uncommon outside of a primary kidney disease. Nutritional deficiency of vitamin D is more likely when the precursor 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration is low. Decreased thyroxine (T concentration (Choice B) presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism including weight gain, lethargy, fatigue, constipation, hair loss, and cold intolerance. Thyroid hormone promotes bone ) 4 mineral density; however, in the absence of additional symptoms of hypothyroidism, a deficiency of thyroxine is less likely. Increased calcitonin concentration (Choice C) classically presents with hypocalcemia, as calcitonin promotes osteoblast activity with resultant bone mineral deposition. Increased osteocalcin concentration (Choice D) is a marker of bone formation and is correlated with increases in bone mineral density, for example, when bone-forming medications such as teriparatide are used. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 36 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
36. A 25-year-old man comes for a routine health maintenance examination. A harsh systolic murmur is heard. Examination shows no other abnormalities . Echocardiography shows a bicuspid aortic valve . This patient is at increased
risk for aortic stenosis as a result of which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Calcification of the valve is a pathologic consequence of mechanical stresses on heart valves and results from repetitive microtrauma from the opening and closing of valve leaflets with associated chronic inflammation. Many people will develop some degree of valve stenosis because of chronic inflammation with resultant calcification and fibrosis over time, with the aortic valve most commonly affected. Structural abnormalities of the valve, such as a bicuspid aortic valve, alter the biomechanics of valve opening and closing, which increases the likelihood of earlier calcification and resultant stenosis because of increased mechanical trauma. Congenital bicuspid aortic valve classically presents with early signs and symptoms of aortic stenosis and left-sided diastolic heart failure. Patients may report fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, diminished exercise tolerance, or syncope with exertion. Examination findings include a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the upper right sternal border, and pulsus parvus et tardus (weak and delayed) may be noted on examination of peripheral pulses. Because of the chronic increased afterload from a fixed obstruction by the valve, left ventricular hypertrophy and resultant diastolic dysfunction can occur. If early aortic stenosis occurs, the patient may be a candidate for aortic valve replacement.

distractor_explanations.B: Formation of atherosclerotic plaque describes the principal risk factor for coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular accidents, and peripheral artery disease. The presence of a plaque within the arterial wall acts as a nidus for thrombus formation when the plaque ruptures. This does not play a role in the development of aortic stenosis. Rupture of the chordae tendineae (Choice C) may occur following a myocardial infarction. It typically leads to acute valvular regurgitation and is classically associated with acute pulmonary edema from mitral regurgitation. Streptococcal infection (Choice D) is associated with rheumatic heart disease, which results in inflammation of the valves of the heart, most commonly the mitral and aortic valves. This may present with acute regurgitant murmurs and chronically can result in stenosis. This patient's bicuspid aortic valve is his main risk factor for early-onset aortic stenosis. Thrombus deposition on the valve (Choice E) is commonly seen in cases of mechanical valve replacement with subtherapeutic anticoagulation. The nonendothelialized valve surface acts as a nidus for thrombus formation. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 37 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
37. An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after she sustained severe head injuries in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. Paramedics report finding a
bottle of amphetamines inside the patient's vehicle . On arrival , her Glasgow Coma Scale score is 6, and she is immediately intubated . Her pulse is 50/min , and blood pressure is 180/90 mm Hg. Examination shows numerous
ecchymoses ; lacerations over the face , trunk , and upper extremities ; and right-sided hemotympanum . There are obvious facial fractures . Except for an abrasion over the right upper quadrant , abdominal examination shows no
abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's increased blood pressure?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this patient's increased blood pressure?

choices.text: Pain response related to the fractures

Exploratory laparotomy (Choice E) involves the surgical evaluation of the peritoneal cavity and is commonly employed in the diagnosis and management of abdominal trauma, bowel obstruction, peritonitis, and undifferentiated cases of an acute abdomen. It does not have an immediate role in the diagnosis or management of cholangiocarcinoma. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
38. A 55-year-old man comes to the physician's office because of claudication . He smokes two packs of cigarettes per day and has no history of diabetes mellitus . The femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally , and distal pulses are
absent. Capillary refill in both feet is less than 5 seconds . Ankle-arm indices are 0.75 on the right and 0.60 on the left. In addition to recommending that he quit smoking , which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in
patient care?

question_stem:
the most appropriate initial step in
patient care?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Prescription for an exercise program is the most appropriate initial step in management for this patient. Leg pain that occurs following exertion and improves with rest is known as claudication and indicates the presence of peripheral vascular disease. Claudication results from increased physiologic demand of the skeletal musculature for oxygen, which cannot be met because of the fixed obstruction to flow of stenotic arteries. As demand falls during rest, the pain typically improves. Peripheral vascular disease is common among older men who smoke cigarettes and have a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or hyperlipidemia. Active exercise improves collateral vascularization, which allows for improved arterial oxygenated blood flow to the skeletal musculature and is the best initial step in treatment along with the mitigation of risk factors. Additional therapeutic options include cilostazol and surgical revascularization (e.g., bypass, stenting), which can be employed following exercise therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: Balloon angioplasty and femoropopliteal bypass (Choice B) are both invasive options that should be reserved for when noninvasive therapy is no longer sufficient.
distractor_explanations.C: Sympathectomy refers to the removal of a sympathetic nerve root and is often used in hyperhidrosis, reflex sympathetic dystrophy, and Raynaud disease. The disease cause of claudication is generally not because of sympathetically mediated vasoconstriction, and sympathectomy does not generally play a role in treatment. Vasodilator therapy (Choice D) (e.g., cilostazol) may have a role in treating this patient's claudication, but it will not promote collateral vascularization which improves long-term symptoms. Because of this, initial treatment with a regimented exercise program is recommended. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 39 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
39. A 51-year-old man comes to the physician 10 days after discovering a nontender mass in his neck. His father and two older brothers were diagnosed with thyroid cancer at the ages of 46 , 46, and 49 years , respectively .
Examination shows a 2-cm nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid gland . A 1-cm, firm , nontender lymph node is palpable in the anterior cervical chain . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Administration of vitamin B (cyanocobalamin) and folic acid

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) occurs most frequently in cirrhotic states, although it can occur in any setting causing ascites. SBP describes an infection within ascitic fluid in the peritoneal cavity, most often from translocated enteric flora such as Escherichia coli. The classic presentation includes fever along with diffuse abdominal pain and tenderness in a patient with ascites. If there is clinical concern for SBP, the ascites fluid should be sampled through a paracentesis. Laboratory analysis of the ascitic fluid should include Gram stain, culture, and cell counts. A total leukocyte count of greater than 1000/mm 3 or greater than 250 neutrophils/mm 3 is generally diagnostic of SBP since culture results are variably positive. Antibiotics with gram-negative rod coverage (e.g., third-generation cephalosporins) are considered first-line.

distractor_explanations.A: Anaplastic carcinoma is a rare, aggressive thyroid malignancy that invades local structures such as the esophagus and trachea. It generally only occurs in older persons and carries a poor prognosis. On examination, a "hard, woody mass" may be palpable along with symptoms of dysphagia or hoarseness. Follicular carcinoma (Choice B) also presents with a thyroid nodule and is the second most common thyroid malignancy after papillary carcinoma. It is diagnosed on biopsy, as the neoplastic cells are noted to invade the surrounding capsule, which differentiates it from a benign follicular adenoma. It typically carries a good prognosis. Hurthle cell adenoma (Choice C) is a less common type of benign thyroid adenoma arising from Hurthle cells. It most commonly occurs in older females. Papillary carcinoma (Choice E) is the most common type of thyroid cancer and carries an excellent prognosis. It typically demonstrates empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies on histology. Early radiation exposure in childhood is a risk factor. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 40 of 50 40 . A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because he has been excessively sleepy for the past 2 days . He was hospitalized 3 weeks ago for an episode of acute pancreatitis . He has a long-standing history of alcoholism but has abstained for 8 weeks . He appears lethargic and does not respond to questions . His temperature is 38.4°C (101 .1° F). Examination shows severe jaundice and peripheral muscle wasting . There are spider angiomata across the neck. Abdominal examination shows distention and a fluid wave ; tenderness cannot be assessed because of his somnolence . Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 11 ,500/mm 3 Prothrombin time 17 sec (INR 1.4) Serum Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dL Creatinine 2.6 mg/dL Albumin 2.0 g/dL Alkaline phosphatase 182 U/L AST 56 U/L ALT 94 U/L Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Abdominal ultrasonography B) Administration of vitamin B (cyanocobalamin) and folic acid 12 C) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography D) Hemodialysis E) Paracentesis Correct Answer: E. Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) occurs most frequently in cirrhotic states, although it can occur in any setting causing ascites. SBP describes an infection within ascitic fluid in the peritoneal cavity, most often from translocated enteric flora such as Escherichia coli. The classic presentation includes fever along with diffuse abdominal pain and tenderness in a patient with ascites. If there is clinical concern for SBP, the ascites fluid should be sampled through a paracentesis. Laboratory analysis of the ascitic fluid should include Gram stain, culture, and cell counts. A total leukocyte count of greater than 1000/mm 3 or greater than 250 neutrophils/mm 3 is generally diagnostic of SBP since culture results are variably positive. Antibiotics with gram-negative rod coverage (e.g., third-generation cephalosporins) are considered first-line. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Abdominal ultrasonography (Choice A) may provide detail as to the presence of ascites and the structural character of the liver. However, in cases with clear signs of liver failure and evidence of ascites on examination, it would delay sampling of the ascites fluid and administration of antibiotics. Administration of vitamin B (cyanocobalamin) and folic acid (Choice B) is important in the repletion of deficient cofactors and coenzymes as a result of the patient's chronic malnutrition. However, such repletion 12 should follow addressing more immediate infectious concerns from SBP. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (Choice C) is a diagnostic and potentially therapeutic intervention for the evaluation of the anatomy and patency of the hepatobiliary tree. It does not have an immediate role in the management of SBP.
distractor_explanations.D: Gastritis presents with abdominal pain, nausea, hematemesis, or melena, and often results from the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, cigarette smoking, or alcohol consumption. It presents as diffuse or patchy regions of erythematous mucosa on upper endoscopy. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 42 of 50

vignette.presentation:
42. A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of mild abdominal cramps , foul-smelling stools , and intermittent diarrhea after meals. He underwent distal pancreatectomy for pancreatitis and chronic pain
3 months ago . He has a history of major depressive disorder and alcoholism ; he has not had a drink for the past year. His medications are esomeprazole , sertraline , and vitamin B complex supplement. He has not had any
recent changes to his diet. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is flat and nontender ; bowel sounds are hyperactive and high pitched . Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 43%
Leukocyte count 12,500/mm 3
Serum
Amylase activity 90 U/L
Lipase activity 100 U/L
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Administration of 100% oxygen by nonrebreather face mask
Administration of 100% oxygen by nonrebreather face mask
Intravenous fluid therapy and blood transfusion
Endoscopic-guided sclerosis of the esophageal varices
Placement of a transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Exocrine and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency are associated with chronic pancreatitis and result from repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis leading to the destruction of acinar and islet cells. The loss of acinar and islet parenchyma can be further exacerbated if a distal pancreatectomy is performed to control symptoms or manage complications of chronic pancreatitis. The exocrine pancreas produces digestive enzymes, the absence of which leads to malnutrition (e.g., cachexia, muscle wasting), weight loss, vitamin deficiencies, and frequent, loose, foul-smelling, sometimes oily stools (steatorrhea). The diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency is through clinical history, imaging, and biopsy. Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is treated with oral pancreatic enzyme replacement such as pancrelipase. Endocrine pancreatic insufficiency, if present, typically results in diabetes mellitus, which requires insulin replacement therapy. Any modifiable inciting causes of pancreatitis (e.g., gallstones, alcohol use disorder, hypertriglyceridemia, hypercalcemia) should be mitigated to delay disease progression and preserve remaining native pancreatic function.

distractor_explanations.A: Cephalocele defines a protrusion of intracranial contents through a defect in the skull, typically covered by skin and dura. They do not classically appear vascular or expand with time. Fat necrosis (Choice B) generally results from a traumatic injury involving adipose tissue and appears erythematous, nodular, and often demonstrates calcifications on imaging. Lesions do not typically persist or expand over time. Lymphatic hypertrophy (Choice C) presents with enlarged lymph nodes or lymphedema and characteristically presents without erythema, except in cases of lymphangitis or chronic dermatitis. Malignant transformation (Choice D) describes the conversion of a benign lesion to a state of malignancy with the potential for metastasis and invasion, which is rare in hemangiomas. Retention cyst (Choice E) describes a benign lesion that arises when a gland is unable to excrete its product, for example, a mucous retention cyst in the oral cavity, or a sebaceous cyst of the skin. Their growth is typically slow and generally not accompanied by symptoms apart from the presence of the lesion. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 46 of 50 'I 46 . A 62-year-old man with alcoholism comes to the emergency department because he has vomited bright red blood three times during the past 6 hours . His pulse is 130/min , and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. He becomes dizzy when he sits up. Abdominal examination shows marked distention, shifting dullness , and a fluid wave . Upper endoscopy shows esophageal varices and an ulcer with a blood clot on a visible vessel located on the posterior wall of the first part of the duodenum . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step? A) Intravenous administration of ADH (vasopressin) B) Intravenous administration of esmolol C) Intravenous fluid therapy and blood transfusion D) Endoscopic-guided sclerosis of the esophageal varices E) Placement of a transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt Correct Answer: C. Tachycardia and hypotension in the setting of gastrointestinal bleeding is diagnostic of decompensated hemorrhagic shock, for which the appropriate immediate treatment includes intravenous fluid therapy and blood transfusion, regardless of the underlying cause of blood loss. Alcohol use disorder promotes the formation of gastric and duodenal ulcers through mucosal irritation and gastritis. If an ulcer erodes through the mucosa and submucosa, marked bleeding can occur from the underlying vessels. Posterior duodenal ulcers are often associated with erosion into the gastroduodenal artery. If bleeding is not promptly addressed with fluid resuscitation, blood transfusion, and endoscopic or surgical control, rapid exsanguination and death can result. Treatment should also include administration of an intravenous proton pump inhibitor. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Intravenous administration of ADH (vasopressin) (Choice A) would not take the place of immediate fluid resuscitation and blood transfusion in a patient with blood loss, tachycardia, and hypotension. It no longer has a recognized role in the immediate management of gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. Intravenous administration of esmolol (Choice B) may worsen the hemodynamics of a patient with hemorrhagic shock and is contraindicated, as it blocks beta-adrenergic receptors resulting in decreased heart rate and myocardial contractility, which in turn decreases cardiac output. In cases of hemorrhagic shock, mean arterial pressure is maintained by systemic vascular resistance and heart rate; stroke volume is often dramatically diminished because of low preload in the setting of blood loss. Endoscopic-guided sclerosis of the esophageal varices (Choice D) is incorrect, as the patient's hemorrhagic shock is secondary to a bleeding duodenal ulcer, not esophageal varices. Any active variceal bleeding would have been noted during the upper endoscopy. Placement of a transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (Choice E) is used in the prevention of variceal bleeding by decreasing portal venous pressure. It does not have an immediate role in the management of a bleeding duodenal ulcer. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 'I 47 . A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of episodes of headache , sweating , and rapid heartbeat. She has not had weight loss or chest pain. She has a 10-year history of hypertension that has been difficult to control despite trials of different drug classes . There is no family history of cancer. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 100/min , respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 172/105 mm Hg. Examination shows no other abnormalities . A 24-hour urine collection shows increased catecholamine and metanephrine concentrations . An MRI of the abdomen shows a 4-cm enhancing mass in the right adrenal gland . Surgical excision of the mass is scheduled . Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy to prepare this patient for surgical removal of the adrenal mass? A) Atropine B) Methylprednisolone C) Phenoxybenzamine D) Propranolol E) Sodium nitroprusside Correct Answer: C. Pheochromocytoma presents with episodic headaches, sweating, palpitations, tremors, agitation, tachycardia, tachypnea, and treatment-refractory hypertension. It is the most common tumor of the adrenal medulla, and is marked by the functional secretion of epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine, which causes episodic hyperadrenergic symptoms. Physical examination may disclose diaphoresis, tremor, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hyperthermia during a symptomatic episode, and may be normal otherwise. Diagnosis is through laboratory evaluation and imaging studies. Laboratory evaluation may disclose increased urine and plasma catecholamines and metanephrines. Imaging studies may disclose a tumor within the adrenal gland, though 10% are extra-adrenal. Treatment includes a-adrenergic blocker such as phenoxybenzamine, an irreversible inhibitor, followed by 13-adrenergic blocker before resection. Failure to administer appropriate antiadrenergic therapy may result in hypertensive crisis or tachydysrhythmia at the time of resection. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E.
distractor_explanations.B: Methylprednisolone is a glucocorticoid with trace mineralocorticoid activity used in the management of allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, multiple sclerosis, and many other rheumatologic, autoimmune, infectious, and neoplastic conditions. It does not have an immediate role in the direct management of pheochromocytoma.
distractor_explanations.D: Propranolol is a nonspecific 13-adrenergic blocker used in the management of panic disorder, social phobia, essential tremor, thyrotoxicosis, tachyarrhythmias, migraines, and portal venous hypertension. It previously had a role in the management of hypertension, angina pectoris, and myocardial infarction, but is no longer a first-line medication for these conditions. It has a potential role in the management of pheochromocytoma but should follow a-adrenergic blocker. Sodium nitroprusside (Choice E) is an intravenous, titratable vasodilator used in the management of hypertensive emergencies; however, it may result in reflex tachycardia in the setting of pheochromocytoma. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 48 of 50 'I 48 . A 57-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-month history of profuse , watery diarrhea with facial flushing . During this period , he has had fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss . The diarrhea has not resolved with use of over-the-counter antidiarrheal medications . He has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications . His pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities . Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun . His stool output is 5 Lover the next 24 hours ; his stool potassium concentration is increased . Serum studies show a pH of 7.56 and a potassium concentration of 2.8 mEq/L. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a pancreatic mass . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Gastrinoma B) Glucagonoma C) lnsulinoma D) Somatostatinoma E) VIPoma Correct Answer: E. VIPoma is a rare tumor often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia that produces vasoactive intestinal peptide {VIP). Through its physiologic mechanism of action, VIP causes chronic and profound watery diarrhea, electrolyte disturbances (e.g., hypokalemia, hypercalcemia), achlorhydria, alkalosis, flushing, and vasodilation. This syndrome is often termed WDHA syndrome (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria). Diagnostic evaluation includes imaging of the abdomen with CT scan or MRI, somatostatin receptor scintigraphy, or PET scan to assist in localization of the tumor, and biopsy for tissue evaluation. Treatment includes correction of the associated fluid, electrolyte, and acid-base derangements, along with surgery and/or chemotherapy. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Gastrinoma {Choice A) is associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, the constellation of findings stemming from a gastrin-secreting tumor. It results in excessive production of acid by the gastric parietal cells. This can lead to recurrent, chronic duodenal or jejunal ulcers, which can present with abdominal pain, diarrhea secondary to malabsorption, and possible hematemesis, melena, or hematochezia. Glucagonoma {Choice B) is a rare functional malignancy that secretes glucagon, which increases serum glucose concentration. Symptoms are nonspecific and include mild diabetes mellitus, paraneoplastic rash (e.g., necrolytic migratory erythema), and weight loss. lnsulinoma {Choice C) is a rare neoplasm of pancreatic islet cells that functionally produces insulin in a dysregulated manner. Insulin is produced even in periods of hypoglycemia. Patients present with symptoms of hypoglycemia, which are generally neuroglycopenic (agitation, headache, blurry vision, diplopia, tremor), autonomic {diaphoresis, tremoring, nausea, vomiting, cramping, tachycardia, anxiety), and nonspecific (fatigue, weakness, lethargy), and are often exacerbated by periods of fasting or exercise. Somatostatinoma {Choice D) is an uncommon neuroendocrine malignancy that presents with weight loss, mild diabetes mellitus, steatorrhea caused by limited cholecystokinin release, and achlorhydria from inhibition of gastrin. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 49 of 50 'I 49 . A previously healthy 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of blurred vision for 2 weeks . His blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes . Funduscopic examination shows slightly pale optic discs . Visual field testing shows bitemporal hemianopia . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Basilar artery aneurysm B) Cavernous sinus thrombosis C) Craniopharyngioma D) Optic nerve glioma E) Pituitary adenoma Correct Answer: E. Pituitary adenoma is associated with bitemporal hemianopsia because of its proximity to the optic chiasm. The nasal (medial) retina receives light entering the eye from temporal (lateral) sources. The fibers from this area of the retina travel within the medial aspect of the optic nerve, and then cross at the optic chiasm to form the optic tract within the contralateral brain. Damage to these fibers anywhere along their course will prevent the patient from perceiving images projected on the retina from the temporal field of view. Classically, patients report poor peripheral vision and a resultant inability to walk or drive as they cannot see things lateral to their bodies. The optic chiasm sits directly superior to the sella turcica, and pituitary adenomas may grow superiorly, compressing the chiasm resulting in loss of a patient's bilateral temporal field of view. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Basilar artery aneurysms (Choice A), when small and unruptured, may be asymptomatic. In cases of rupture or thrombosis, the posterior intracranial circulation may be affected, and patients can present with headache, cranial nerve deficits, nausea, vomiting, vertigo, and ataxia. Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Choice B) classically follows an infection or injury involving a structure drained by the cavernous sinus (e.g., sinusitis), and results in cranial nerve deficits involving those that traverse the cavernous sinus (oculomotor, trochlear, trigeminal, and abducens nerves). Classic symptoms include ipsilateral orbit pain, proptosis, periorbital edema, and impairment in extraocular movement, pupil reactivity, or symmetry.
distractor_explanations.C: Craniopharyngioma is a tumor seen in the sella turcica derived from remnants of Rathke pouch. It is the most common supratentorial tumor in childhood, although it is much less common than pituitary adenomas in adults. When large, they can compress the optic chiasm and cause bitemporal hemianopsia. Optic nerve glioma (Choice D) typically presents with unilateral vision loss or an afferent pupillary defect. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 50 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
50. While undergoing a splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura , a 49-year-old man aspirates during a difficult intubation . The diagnosis is confirmed when bile is aspirated from the trachea . Which of the following factors
is most predictive of the severity of the resulting aspiration pneumonia?

choices.text: Amount of bile present in the aspirate
Presence of solid material in the aspirate

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The inhalation of orogastric contents is known as aspiration, and it can occur from simple fluids such as water or stomach contents such as emesis or regurgitated products. Small volume, simple fluid aspiration may be resorbed by the lung without any consequence of infection, irritation, or compromised gas exchange. In other cases, large volume aspiration may sufficiently impair gas exchange resulting in refractory hypoxia. The aspiration of acidic stomach contents may cause aspiration pneumonitis, whereas the aspiration of gastrointestinal flora and additional bacteria can cause aspiration pneumonia. The volume of aspirate is the strongest predictor of complications from aspiration, especially in the case of pneumonia, as the bacterial inoculum may overwhelm the native ability of the pulmonary alveolar defenses (macrophages, cilia, mucus) to prevent colonization, replication, and infection. Aspiration pneumonia classically presents with cough productive of foul-smelling sputum, fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, and rhonchi on examination. Imaging classically shows an infiltrate in the most dependent segments of lung at the time of aspiration (e.g., in the superior segment of the inferior lobe when supine or lower lobes when erect), and treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics with sufficient coverage of oral flora, gram-negative rods, and anaerobes.

distractor_explanations.A: Amount of bile present in the aspirate may be a factor in determining the severity of a noninfectious aspiration pneumonitis but would not play an immediate role in predicting the severity of an aspiration pneumonia. Duration of endotracheal intubation (Choice B) increases the risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia, which is not characteristically caused by oral flora. Typical organisms include Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Presence of solid material in the aspirate (Choice C) increases the risk for airway obstruction and atelectasis following aspiration, and also increases the risk for pneumonia, but to a lesser extent than the overall volume of aspiration fluid. Use of prophylactic antibiotics preoperatively (Choice D) is indicated to prevent skin and soft-tissue infections, contamination from the operative incision, sepsis, and peritonitis in the case of intra-abdominal surgery. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
1. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 3-hour history of severe pain in his right testicle . He has not sustained any recent trauma and has no history of serious illness . His
temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min , and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities . The right testicle is high in the right hemiscrotum , transverse , and
exquisitely tender to palpation . The left hemiscrotum is normal. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Application of an ice pack to the right hemiscrotum
Technetium Tc 99m sestamibi scan of the testes

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Surgical exploration of the scrotum is indicated for the management of testicular torsion. Testicular torsion occurs when the testicle twists on the spermatic cord, resulting in subsequent insufficient testicular blood supply. Patients typically present with acute, severe testicular pain, swelling, and erythema. On physical examination, the testicle typically demonstrates an abnormal lie (e.g., transverse), extreme tenderness to palpation, absent cremasteric reflex, and pain that does not improve with elevation of the scrotum (as it does in epididymitis). The diagnosis is often clinical, though in cases of uncertainty, evaluation begins with ultrasonography, which delineates testicular size, sonographic features, blood flow, and epididymal anatomy. Management requires immediate surgical exploration of the scrotum with detorsion of the spermatic cord followed by bilateral orchiopexy to prevent future testicular torsion.

distractor_explanations.A: Transillumination of the right hemiscrotum is used to differentiate a hydrocele from a varicocele. Hydroceles characteristically transilluminate with the application of light to the scrotum, while varicoceles do not. Application of an ice pack to the right hemiscrotum (Choice B) can be used for symptomatic treatment in epididymitis and orchitis to attempt to relieve inflammation and swelling. Technetium Tc 99m sestamibi scan of the testes (Choice C) can be used to evaluate testicular blood flow; however, this technique is outdated as advances in technology make ultrasonography the first-line diagnostic imaging exam for the evaluation of testicular torsion. Intravenous administration of antibiotics (Choice D) may be necessary for severe cases of epididymitis or orchitis. These typically present as acute unilateral scrotal pain, swelling, and erythema, with decreased pain on scrotal elevation and evidence of abnormally increased vascularity on testicular Doppler ultrasonography. r , " , F' Exam Section : Item 2 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
2. A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of chest pain, fatigue , shortness of breath , and a nonproductive cough . The chest pain is exacerbated by inspiration or lying down and is relieved when he
leans forward. Three weeks ago , he underwent three-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting . His initial postoperative course was uncomplicated , and he was discharged 16 days ago . His temperature is 38.2°C (100 .8°F), pulse is
85/min and regular , and respirations are 14/min . The lungs are clear to auscultation . A friction rub is heard best over the left anterior chest. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities . An ECG is unchanged from the ECG taken
on discharge . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Venous duplex ultrasonography of the lower extremities

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Echocardiography is indicated for the assessment of a pericardia! effusion in the setting of postoperative pericarditis. Pericarditis classically presents as substernal chest pain, which is often pleuritic, worsens when lying down, and improves with leaning forward. It can occur in patients with inflammatory, infectious, or malignant conditions, such as viral infection, systemic lupus erythematosus, tuberculosis, and lymphoma, and can present as a complication of myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery. On examination, pericarditis demonstrates a diastolic friction rub, described as a harsh sound heard in diastole. The condition is diagnosed clinically and supported by increased inflammatory markers such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. If not treated, pericarditis can lead to the development of pericardia! effusions, which, if large and quickly accumulating, can result in cardiac tamponade. An echocardiography should be performed to assess for the presence of a pericardia! effusion, which may require pericardiocentesis for drainage if large. Treatment includes anti-inflammatory medications, such as indomethacin, glucocorticoids, and/or colchicine. Conditions with a similar presentation, such as acute myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and aortic dissection, should also be ruled out.

distractor_explanations.B: Venous duplex ultrasonography of the lower extremities is used primarily to evaluate for the presence or absence of deep venous thrombosis. This patient presents as findings of postoperative pericarditis, not venous thromboembolic disease. Myocardial biopsy (Choice C) is invasive and presents significant risk. It is used to assess cardiac allograft rejection, sarcoidosis, giant cell myocarditis, hypereosinophilic syndrome, and anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiography (Choice D) is an invasive test performed via percutaneous catheter to assess the anatomy and patency of the coronary arteries. It is indicated for the diagnostic and therapeutic management of acute coronary syndrome (e.g .. , ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction) and for the management of chronic coronary artery disease following an abnormal stress test. Pulmonary angiography (Choice E) constitutes invasive catheter angiographic evaluation of the pulmonary arteries. This is no longer necessary for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism given advances in ventilation perfusion scans and CT pulmonary angiography, but it may still be performed if pulmonary embolectomy is required. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 3 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
3. A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a mole on her left cheek because her uncle was recently diagnosed with widely metastatic melanoma . She has had the mole for 15 years , and there have been no
recent changes . Examination of the left cheek shows a 0.5-cm , smooth , dome shaped , round , brown papule nevus with distinct symmetric borders . A 4-mm , smooth , moveable left posterior cervical lymph node is palpated . Which
of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Biopsy of the inguinal lymph node
Excisional biopsy of the nevus with a rim of normal skin

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Observation only is indicated for a nevus without suspicious features concerning for malignant melanoma. Malignant melanoma is likely to be present when a skin lesion demonstrates asymmetry, irregular-appearing borders, variable coloration, a diameter greater than 6 mm, and rapid evolution in characteristics. As well, lymph nodes are suspicious when they are greater than 1 cm, irregular, nontender, and immobile on physical examination. This patient exhibits a nonsuspicious nevus of the left cheek and a nonsuspicious posterior cervical lymph node.

distractor_explanations.B: Biopsy of the inguinal lymph node is not indicated, as this patient presents as a normal-appearing lymph node of the left posterior cervical lymph node. There is no suspicious lymph node mentioned within the inguinal region. Excisional biopsy of the nevus with a rim of normal skin (Choice C), incisional biopsy of the nevus (Choice D), and needle biopsy of the nevus (Choice E) are all potential options for evaluation of a suspicious skin lesion. This patient presents with a nevus that does not have suspicious features for malignant melanoma. Any lesion with features suggestive of malignant melanoma should undergo excisional biopsy with assessment of margins and depth of dermal invasion. Malignant melanoma has the ability to rapidly invade and metastasize, which carries a poor prognosis when diagnosed late. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 4 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
4. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of pain and burning of his right eye after playing in a sandbox . Although he insists that something is in his eye and he continues to rub it, no foreign body is apparent. He also
states that his vision is blurry in the right eye . There is moderate conjunctiva! injection with marked tearing and photophobia . The pupils are equal , round , and reactive to light and accommodation . Funduscopic examination shows
no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Conjunctiva! instillation of fluorescein is indicated for the evaluation of a potential corneal abrasion or residual corneal or conjunctiva! foreign body. A corneal abrasion is one of the most common eye injuries and occurs secondary to disruption of the top layer of the cornea (corneal epithelium), which can occur spontaneously or from traumatic injury from a foreign body (e.g., contact lens, sand, workplace debris). Patients typically present with eye discomfort, blurry vision, photophobia, difficulty opening the eye, and a foreign body sensation. Physical examination may demonstrate excessive lacrimation, conjunctiva! erythema, decreased visual acuity, and increased light sensitivity. Fluorescein staining is indicated to assess for a corneal injury. Fluorescein passes over intact corneal tissue but is trapped in epithelial defects, which are easily visualized under a blacklight. Treatment requires removal of any residual foreign body, copious irrigation with 0.9% saline, administration of cycloplegic eye drops, and topical antibiotics if a large abrasion is present.

distractor_explanations.A: Indirect funduscopy allows for visualization of posterior eye anatomy, especially the retina, and is necessary for diagnostic evaluation of retinal diseases such as retinal detachment, macular degeneration, and diabetic retinopathy. Measurement of intraocular pressure (Choice B) is indicated for the evaluation of glaucoma. Glaucoma typically presents as acute or chronic visual field deficits secondary to increased intraocular pressure and does not generally result from corneal or conjunctiva! foreign bodies.
